filtered_stories.title: Commenting guidelines
filtered_stories.date: PublicSource loves to hear from youWe’re here to help you understand important issues in Pennsylvania, and we want to know how we’re doing. We rely on you to give us constructive, insightful feedback on our stories and on how they effect you and your community. We also want you to keep our coverage fresh by sharing your own insights and experiences with the community PublicSource readers.To help facilitate the conversation, we’ve put together some guidelines so you’ll know what we think is harmful or inappropriate. Harmful, inappropriate content will be removed and repeat offenders can be banned from contributing in the future.These guidelines apply to comments and reactions on any PublicSource site or platform including social media platforms.We also reserve the right to delete any and all posts that we feel are inappropriate.No foul language.Foul language includes but is not limited to swear words, racial slurs, sexist talk or homophobic outbursts. Also, please don’t slightly misspell swear words to get them past our filtering. We might not catch you right away, but we will catch you eventually and we will not be pleased.Aggressive behavior.Please don’t try and harm others with your comments. We consider it aggressive and harmful to disclose personal information about other people. We also consider terroristic threats against PublicSource, our sources, our media partners or any other person or organization to be unacceptable. Smear tactics will not be tolerated either.Self promotion.Don’t use our commenting section to promote your business. Unless your business is something that directly relates to one of our stories and your post is about public service or helping others, it will be deemed spam, and removed.Excessive and off-topic commenting.If you post too frequently, if your posts are extremely long or if your comments are off topic, you might receive a warning from us. If you fail to respect our request, we reserve the right to ban you.Respect.Show it. Receive it. Spread it around.Thanks for reading and if you have any questions, please feel free to contact Alexandra Kanik at alexandra@publicsource.org.

filtered_stories.title: Was it something we said?
filtered_stories.date: We noticed that you didn’t complete your donation to PublicSource and we wanted to know if there was anything we can do to help you finish. Remember that PublicSource does not charge for its content because we are dedicated to providing Pennsylvanians with information everyone should see.Without the contributions of loyal viewers like you, we would not be able to bring you in-depth news about crucial issues.If you have any questions or comments, please feel free to contact PublicSource editor, Sharon Walsh at swalsh@publicsource.org.

filtered_stories.title: You’re all set!
filtered_stories.date: Congratulations! You will now receive PublicSource’s latest stories as soon as they are available.Manage your preferences*To update your profile, click the link above, enter your email address on the following page, click “Subscribe to list”, then click the “Click here to update your profile” link.

filtered_stories.title: So sorry to see you go
filtered_stories.date: You have been successfully removed from the PublicSource newsletter list.You will receive one final email to confirm that we unsubscribed you.

filtered_stories.title: Volunteer
filtered_stories.date: If you’re a fan of the in-depth newsPublicSourceprovides, volunteering is a great way to support our work and get to know us. If you’re interested in becoming a volunteer, please email Stephanie Roman atsroman@publicsource.org.Include yourname, email address and phone numberin your email so we can contact you when we need volunteers. And let us know which of these opportunities you’re interested in.Here are some of the things you might be able to help us with:*Events.PublicSourcehas events to discuss the subjects of our stories — usually with panelists who are experts on the issue — and engage the community about their questions. On event day we need help with taking tickets, readying the space for the event, picking up necessary items and helping sign attendees up for our newsletter.*Ambassadors. Are you going to a meeting or lecture where you might be able to tell people aboutPublicSourceand its work? Could you take a sign-up sheet and invite them to sign up for our free newsletter?*Fundraisers. Events where we raise money for the work ofPublicSourceare lots of fun. But we may need help picking up items that have been donated for our silent auction or taking tickets at the door or making sure the band setup goes smoothly.*Administrative support. Do you have a special talent? Like helping send our stories out on social media or making phone calls to people who might want to sign up for membership?If you have a few hours to spare and can help out as aPublicSourcevolunteer, contact Stephanie Roman atsroman@publicsource.orgwith your name, email address and phone number.We look forward to meeting you!
